title: 107_s22
content: The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updating penalty amounts. SEC. 101. ADDITIONAL MONTHLY AND QUARTERLY DISCLOSURE REPORTS. Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 requires additional monthly and quarterly reports from Principal Campaign Committees. Monthly reports are due by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 mandates monthly reports for Principal Campaign Committees, with exceptions for November and December. Quarterly reports are also required, due by the 15th day after each calendar quarter. The Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports for Principal Campaign Committees. SEC. 102 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require national political party committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. If a committee receives or spends over $200 from a person in a calendar year, it must itemize the reporting for that person. Reports must be filed for the same time periods as political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 provides public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 requires licensees to maintain and make public a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. This includes requests made by or on behalf of candidates for public office and messages concerning national legislative issues. The record must include information on whether the request was accepted or rejected by the licensee. The licensee must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including details such as rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, and contact information for the purchaser. The licensee must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including details such as rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, and contact information for the purchaser. Information required must be placed in a political file as soon as possible and retained for a period of not less than 2 years. SEC. 105 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost. Any person required to file reports must use the software provided. SEC. 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes a limit on soft money of national political party committees. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Limitation on donations to political party committees and individuals, with an aggregate limit of $60,000 per person per calendar year, subject to adjustment based on the price index. Expedited Review and Appeal Process: Any individual or entity affected by section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 can bring a legal action in the US District Court for the District of Columbia to challenge its constitutionality. Orders from the District Court can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. Both courts are required to prioritize and expedite these cases. States must expedite the disposition of any matter brought under subsection (a). The enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 will be stayed until the Supreme Court of the United States makes a final decision on any action filed under subsection (a). This section applies only to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. SEC. 203 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase individual and political committee contribution limits. The amendments include raising the limits from $1,000 to $3,000, $20,000 to $60,000, $5,000 to $15,000, $25,000 to $75,000, and adjusting multicandidate limits from $5,000 to $7,500. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The limits are raised to $30,000, $7,500, and $15,000 for various categories, with adjustments made for multicandidate limits. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The limits are raised to $60,000 for Senate candidate contributions by national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. Effective dates for the amendments are specified. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to raise contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The effective dates for the amendments are specified as after December 31, 2001, except for subsection (c) which applies after December 31, 2002. SEC. 301 prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. It amends Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, to define "contribution" and include a prohibition of donations. SEC. 302 updates penalty amounts under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 based on inflation after 2001. SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require all designations, statements, and reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to various sections to reflect this change.
